elements.content: One new polyoxometalate compound H3(Tea)(Bmim)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Tea = triethylamine, Bmim = 1-methyl-3-ethylimidazole) (1) and three new polyoxometalate-based metal−organic frameworks (PMOFs) CuII(Bbi)1.5(H2Bbi)2[P2W18O62] (Bbi = 1,1-(1,4-butanediyl)-bis(imidazole)) (2), CuII 2.5(Mimin)(HMimin)(Bbi)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Mimin = methylimidazol) (3), and CuII(Bbtz)(H2Bbi)(H2Btp)[P2W18O62] (Bbtz = 1,4-bis(triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, Btp = 1,3-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane) (4) have been synthesized under ionothermal conditions using an ionic liquid (IL) [Bmim]Br (Bmim = 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazole) as solvent. Their structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 possesses a one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular chain-like structure constructed from [P2W18O62]6− anions, Bmim, Tea, and water molecules. Compound 2 has a two-dimensional (2D) (6,3)-layer structure built by [P2W18O62]6− anions, copper ions, and Bbi ligands. Compounds 3 and 4 are three-dimensional (3D) PMOFs with novel (6.8.10)(4.6.83.10)(4.6.83.12) and classic (65.8)(65.8)-cds topologies, respectively. Compounds 2−4 represent the first examples of PMOFs synthesized by the ionothermal method. The successful synthesis of compounds 2−4 suggests that ionothermal synthesis will be a very promising synthetic technique for assembling new PMOFs. Additionally, the properties of the four compounds have been studied in detail.

elements.content: Using an ionic liquid (IL) [Bmim]Br (Bmim = 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium) as solvent has resulted in one new polyoxometalate structure and three new polyoxometalate-based metal−organic frameworks (PMOFs) for the first time. They are H3(Tea)(Bmim)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Tea = triethylamine, Bmim = 1-methyl-3-ethyl imidazole) (1), CuII(Bbi)1.5(H2Bbi)2[P2W18O62] (Bbi = 1,1-(1,4-butanediyl)-bis(imida-zole)) (2), CuII 2.5(Mimin)(HMimin)(Bbi)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Mimin = methylimidazol) (3), and CuII(Bbtz)(H2Bbi)(H2Btp)[P2W18O62] (Bbtz = 1,4-bis(triazol-1-ylmethyl)benz-ene, Btp = 1,3-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane) (4), produced via a ionothermal route. In compound 1, we introduced Tea to synthetize Wells-Dawson type polyoxometalates (POMs) under ionothermal conditions. Compound 2 is a two-dimensional (6,3)-layer. Compounds 3 and 4 are both three-dimensional PMOFs with novel (6.8.10)(4.6.83.10)(4.6.83.12) and classic (65.8)(65.8)-cds topologies, respectively. These results mean that the use of ILs to synthesize PMOFs can be efficiently realized.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of polyoxometalate (POM)-based metal−organic frameworks (PMOFs) have attracted great interest in functional solid-state materials, owing to their applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and drug delivery. The chemical self-assembly question during the synthesis has been a hot topic in the field of synthetic chemistry. So it is very urgent and necessary for researchers to explore reasonable and new synthetic methods to obtain PMOFs materials. The ionothermal synthesis has been successfully applied in the metal−organic frameworks (PMOFs) synthesis field recently, and many metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) materials synthesized by ionothermal methods have already been reported. However, to date, no PMOFs obtained under the ionothermal conditions have been reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of polyoxometalate (POM)-based metal-organic frameworks (PMOFs) have attracted great interest in functional solid-state materials, owing to their applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and drug delivery. The chemical self-assembly question during the synthesis has been a hot topic in the field of synthetic chemistry. So it is very urgent and necessary for researchers to explore reasonable and new synthetic methods to obtain PMOFs materials. The ionothermal synthesis has been successfully applied in the metal-organic frameworks (PMOFs) synthesis field recently, and many metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) materials synthesized by ionothermal methods have already been reported. However, to date, no PMOFs obtained under the ionothermal conditions have been reported.

elements.content: Ionothermal synthesis is one kind of synthetic method in which ionic liquids (ILs) act as the solvents, potential templates, or structural directing agents in the formation of solid materials. Compared to the solvents used in traditional hydro/solvothermal synthesis, ILs possess better solubility to most of the inorganic precursors, lower vapor pressures, higher chemical and thermal stabilities, and lower toxicities. Moreover, introducing the ionothermal synthesis method to the synthesis of the PMOFs may bring the following advantages: first, the weak coordinating ability of the ILs may make the reaction environments beneficial to the self-assembly of the polyoxoanions. Second, the good solubility of the ILs for inorganic precursors can greatly improve the reactivity of the species in the reaction system, which could not be achieved by traditional hydro/solvothermal synthesis. Third, in ionothermal synthesis almost no competition exists between solvents and frameworks as what happened in hydro/solvothermal synthesis, which reduces the complexities of the whole reaction system. In addition, research shows that the trace water molecules existing in ionic liquids evenly distribute to the whole system at the molecular level, or form small water clusters distributing evenly in the solvents, thereby greatly reducing the activity of the water molecules. Fourth, the existence of the trace hydration halide ions in ILs may promote the growth and crystallinity of the open framework compounds. Finally, the ILs possess tunable acidity, which may offer alterable reaction environments to satisfy the pH conditions demanded by the syntheses of different types of polyoxoanions.

elements.content: On the basis of the above considerations, we try to synthesize PMOFs under ionothermal conditions. Using IL 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([Bmim]Br) as a solvent, one new POMs-based hybrid H3(Tea)(Bmim)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Tea = triethylamine, Bmim = 1-methyl-3-ethylimidazole) (1) and three new PMOFs CuII(Bbi)1.5(H2Bbi)2[P2W18O62] (Bbi = 1,1-(1,4-butanediyl)-bis(imidazole)) (2), CuII 2.5(Mimin)(HMimin) (Bbi)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (Mimin = methylimidazol) (3), and CuII(Bbtz)(H2Bbi)(H2Btp)[P2W18O62] (Bbtz = 1,4-bis(triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, Btp = 1,3-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane) (4) have been successfully synthesized. Compounds 2−4 represent the first examples of PMOFs synthesized under ionothermal conditions. The properties of the four compounds have been carefully investigated especially the photocatalytic and electrocatalytic properties of compounds 2−4.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analysis of W, Si, P, and Cu were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer, and at the same time, C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained by a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (cpes) were used as working electrodes. Excitation and emission spectra were obtained on a SPEX FL-2T2 spectrofluorometer equipped with a 450-W xenon lamp as the excitation source. UV−vis absorption spectra were recorded on a 756 CRT UV−vis spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analysis of W, Si, P, and Cu were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer, and at the same time, C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained by a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (cpes) were used as working electrodes. Excitation and emission spectra were obtained on a SPEX FL-2T2 spectrofluorometer equipped with a 450-W xenon lamp as the excitation source. UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a 756 CRT UV-vis spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of [Bmim]Br (2 g, 4.6 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.6 g, 1.8 mmol), 85% H3PO4 (0.1 mL), and Tea (0.15 mL) were stirred for about half an hour at room temperature. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and kept at 180 °C for five days. After the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, it stood for one day. Then the autoclave was opened, and the obtained black crystals were filtered off, washed with acetone, and dried in a desiccator (yield 72% based on W). The initial and final pH values of the solutions are 4.50 and 7.01, respectively. Elemental analysis for H3(Tea)(Bmim)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (1) calcd: C, 5.98; H, 1.00; N, 2.03; P, 1.28; W, 68.68 (%); found: C, 4.01; H, 1.01; N, 1.37; P, 1.32; W, 69.07 (%).

elements.content: Diffractive quality single crystals were mounted on a glass fiber and the crystallographic data of 1−4 were collected at 150(2) K on a Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. The structures of 1−4 were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine not all non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms on the C atoms were included in calculated positions. The H atoms on water molecules cannot be found from the weak residual electron peaks but directly included in the final molecular formula. The detailed crystal data and structure refinement for 1−4 were summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths of them are given in Table S2 (see the ). Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre (CCDC) as deposition numbers CCDC 784711−784714 for 1−4. The data can be obtained, free of charge, from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK via fax (+44 1223 336033) or e-mail (deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Diffractive quality single crystals were mounted on a glass fiber and the crystallographic data of 1-4 were collected at 150(2) K on a Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. The structures of 1-4 were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine not all non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms on the C atoms were included in calculated positions. The H atoms on water molecules cannot be found from the weak residual electron peaks but directly included in the final molecular formula. The detailed crystal data and structure refinement for 1-4 were summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths of them are given in Table S2 (see the ). Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre (CCDC) as deposition numbers CCDC 784711-784714 for 1-4. The data can be obtained, free of charge, from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK via fax (+44 1223 336033) or e-mail (deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

The successful isolation of compounds 1−4 depends on the ionothermal synthesis strategy. Ionothermal synthesis will be a very promising synthetic technique for assembling novel PMOFs.

Structure Description of <bold>1</bold>

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that compound 1 has a 1D supramolecular chain-like structure constructed from one [P2W18O62]6− anion, three dissociative protonated water molecules, three dissociative protonated Bmim, and one dissociative Tea molecules (). The [P2W18O62]6− anion is of classical α-[P2W18O62]6− structure. The α-[P2W18O62]6− (abbreviated to P2W18) anion is the inorganic building block of compounds 1−4, which contains two [α-A-PW9O34]9− units derived from an α-Keggin anion by removal of a set of three corner-shared WO6 octahedra. Its W−O distances can be grouped into three sets: W−Ot (terminal) 1.65(2)−1.74(2) Å, W−Ob (bridge) 1.85(2)−1.98(3) Å, and W−Oc (central) 2.338(2)−2.45(2) Å. The central P atoms exhibit tetrahedral coordination modes with the P−O bond lengths in the range of 1.49(2)−1.59(2) Å. The P−O and W−O lengths are in the normal ranges. Bond valence sum calculations show that all tungsten atoms are in +VI oxidation state.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis Discussion

The successful isolation of compounds 1-4 depends on the ionothermal synthesis strategy. Ionothermal synthesis will be a very promising synthetic technique for assembling novel PMOFs.

Structure Description of 1 

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that compound 1 has a 1D supramolecular chain-like structure constructed from one [P2W18O62]6- anion, three dissociative protonated water molecules, three dissociative protonated Bmim, and one dissociative Tea molecules (). The [P2W18O62]6- anion is of classical α-[P2W18O62]6- structure. The α-[P2W18O62]6- (abbreviated to P2W18) anion is the inorganic building block of compounds 1-4, which contains two [α-A-PW9O34]9- units derived from an α-Keggin anion by removal of a set of three corner-shared WO6 octahedra. Its W-O distances can be grouped into three sets: W-Ot (terminal) 1.65(2)-1.74(2) Å, W-Ob (bridge) 1.85(2)-1.98(3) Å, and W-Oc (central) 2.338(2)-2.45(2) Å. The central P atoms exhibit tetrahedral coordination modes with the P-O bond lengths in the range of 1.49(2)-1.59(2) Å. The P-O and W-O lengths are in the normal ranges. Bond valence sum calculations show that all tungsten atoms are in +VI oxidation state.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 contains one P2W18 anion, one crystallographically independent Cu(II) atom, and two and a half Bbi organic ligands in the asymmetric unit. It is interesting that the Bbi organic ligands in 2 can be divided into three groups (): one dissociative protonated Bbi ligand, a half two-coordinated Bbi ligand, and one monocoordinated Bbi ligand (). In 2, each Cu(II) atom has a four-coordinated distorted tetrahedron geometry which is defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different Bbi organic ligands with the distances of Cu1−N4, 1.876(2); Cu1−N5, 1.892(2) Å and two equator-positioned terminal oxygen atoms from the P2W18 anion with Cu1−O49, 2.9535(1); Cu1−O60, 2.5255(1) Å, (). Adjacent P2W18 anions are connected through Cu1 atoms by equator-positioned terminal oxygen atoms to generate a 1D chain. The adjacent chains are further connected through Cu1 atoms and the two-coordinated Bbi ligands into a (6,3)-layer (Figure a,b).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 3 contains one P2W18 anion, two and a half crystallographically independent Cu(II) atoms, two methylimidazole and three Bbi ligands (). The methylimidazole in 3 could be divided into two groups: one is dissociative protonated methylimidazole, and the other is monocoordinated methylimidazole (). The two and a half independent Cu(II) atoms can be divided into three groups Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3. Each Cu1 has a five-coordinated pyramidal geometry which is defined by one terminal oxygen atoms from the [P2W18] Dawson anion with Cu1−O28, 2.4017(2) Å, one nitrogen atom from methylimidazole, and three nitrogen atoms from Bbi organic ligands. Each Cu2 has a four-coordinated cross-shaped geometry which is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms from the P2W18 Dawson anion with Cu2−O46, 2.8499(2); Cu2−O49, 2.7859(2) Å and two nitrogen atoms from Bbi ligands with Cu2−N9, 1.87(3) Å; Cu2−N10, 1.9(4) Å (). Each Cu3 has a six-coordinated octahedral geometry which is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms from the P2W18 Dawson anion with Cu3−O52, 2.5566(2) Å and four oxygen atoms from water molecules (). In turn, each P2W18 anion has four-coordinated cross-shaped geometry, which is defined by one Cu1, two Cu2, and one Cu3 atoms (). In 3, Cu1 and Cu2 were connected by Bbi ligands into 1D chains (Figure ), and these 1D chains were connected by P2W18 anions through Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 atoms to generate a 3D framework with (6.8.10)(4.6.83.10)(4.6.83.12) topology (Figure ).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 4 contains one P2W18 anion, two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms in the asymmetric unit (). Two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms can be divided into two sets (Cu1 and Cu2). Each Cu1 cation has a six-coordinated distorted octahedral geometry which is defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different Bbtz ligands with the distances of Cu1−N14, 1.957(1) Å, two pole-positioned terminal-oxygen atoms from the [P2W18] anion with Cu1−O54, 2.4735(2) Å, and two nitrogen atoms from two different Btp molecules with the distances of Cu1−N10, 1.906(2) Å (). Each Cu2 cation possesses a four-coordinated cross-shaped geometry which is defined by two equator-positioned terminal oxygen atoms from two adjacent P2W18 anion with Cu2−O14, 2.8243(2) Å, and two nitrogen atoms from two different Bbtz ligands with the distances of Cu2−N7, 1.906(2) Å (). Adjacent Cu1 cations are connected through Bbtz ligands to generate 1D metal−organic chains, which are further connected with Cu2 atoms through P2W18 anions to form 2D layers (Figure b). The Cu2 atoms from different 2D sheets are linked together by Bbtz ligands to form a unique 3D PMOF with a classic (65.8)(65.8)-cds topology (Figure a,c). Furthermore, the 3D framework is penetrated by dissociative Bbi-ligand molecules (). The space situated by free Bbi-ligand molecules in 4 is 24% of the total volume calculated by PLATON software.

elements.content: We summarized the information of the syntheses and structures of compounds 1−4 in Scheme . First, we obtained compound 1 using H3PO4, Na2WO4·2H2O, and organic ligand Tea under ionothermal conditions. At the same time, we also introduced Bbi and methylimidazole ligands into the reaction system to substitute Tea and obtained crystalline compounds, but the crystal data of these compounds were not good enough to be reported. The successful synthesis of 1 proves that it is possible to introduce organic ligands into the structure of POM-based hybrid under ionothermal conditions. However, in the previous work, only POM-based hybrids constructed by discrete POM clusters and ILs as counterions have been prepared under ionothermal conditions. This work encourages us to try to synthesize PMOFs under ionothermal conditions. Compound 2 was first synthesized, which possesses a 2D lamellar structure with (6, 3)-layer topology. It is very interesting that the organic ligands Bbi in 2 possess three kinds of coordination modes (bis-monodentate, monodentate, dissociative). Having this in mind, we try to introduce different kinds of N-containing ligands (flexible or/and rigid organic ligands) to obtain more complex 3D structures or porous structures. Compound 3 was then synthesized. In 3, rigid methylimidazole organic ligands participate in the construction of POMFs together with Bbi ligands. There were also some free methylimidazole molecules in the structure of 3, so we obtained a kind of PMOF with two types of N-containing ligands in one system. The structure became more complicated due to the heavy distortion of the flexible Bbi ligands, and the solvent accessible volume is 6.7% of total volume. In order to further increase the porous volume, we adopted the Bbtz ligand with both flexible and rigid properties together with Bbi and Btp ligands to synthesize PMOFs. Consquently, compound 4 was synthesized by adding three kinds of N-containing organic ligands, Bbi, Bbtz, and Btp, into the reaction system. Bbtz and Btp ligands participated in the coordinations, and Bbi was dissociative in the hole of the asymmetric unit. As a result, we achieved a good example of PMOFs containing three kinds of N-contained ligands with the solvent accessible volume up to 24%. Compounds 3 and 4 possess novel (6.8.10)(4.6.83.10)(4.6.83.12) and classic (65.8)(65.8)-cds topologies, respectively (Scheme ). This is the first time PMOFs were successfully synthesized in ionic liquids (compounds 2−4).

elements.content: Compound 2 was synthesized from the reaction system containing Na2WO4·2H2O, H3PO4, copper cations, and flexible Bbi ligand. Commonly, the combination of flexible ligand and inorganic unit is inclined to form a low dimensional structure, while the combination of rigid ligand and inorganic unit is inclined to generate a three-dimensional structure. As expected, compound 2 displays a 2D layer structure. For building a 3D structure from a 2D structure, a directly strategy is choosing a suitable rigid ligand to pillar the 2D layer. However, from a crystal engineering point of view, it is still a challenge to introduce an extra rigid ligand to a system containing a flexible ligand. In this work, when relatively rigid Mimin and Bbtz ligands were introduced into the reaction system for synthesizing 2, compounds 3 and 4 possessing a 3D structure were obtained. In the structure of compounds 3 and 4, Mimin and Bbtz exert their rigid nature, which pillar the 2D structure formed by the Dawson anion, Cu atom, and flexible ligand into the 3D structure. Therefore, the rigid nature of Mimin and Bbtz ligands plays a key role in the structural change from a 2D layer to 3D framework ().
elements.clean_text:
The Roles of Rigid Mimin and Bbtz Organic Ligands for Tuning the Low Dimensional structure to Three-Dimensional Structure

Compound 2 was synthesized from the reaction system containing Na2WO4⋅2H2O, H3PO4, copper cations, and flexible Bbi ligand. Commonly, the combination of flexible ligand and inorganic unit is inclined to form a low dimensional structure, while the combination of rigid ligand and inorganic unit is inclined to generate a three-dimensional structure. As expected, compound 2 displays a 2D layer structure. For building a 3D structure from a 2D structure, a directly strategy is choosing a suitable rigid ligand to pillar the 2D layer. However, from a crystal engineering point of view, it is still a challenge to introduce an extra rigid ligand to a system containing a flexible ligand. In this work, when relatively rigid Mimin and Bbtz ligands were introduced into the reaction system for synthesizing 2, compounds 3 and 4 possessing a 3D structure were obtained. In the structure of compounds 3 and 4, Mimin and Bbtz exert their rigid nature, which pillar the 2D structure formed by the Dawson anion, Cu atom, and flexible ligand into the 3D structure. Therefore, the rigid nature of Mimin and Bbtz ligands plays a key role in the structural change from a 2D layer to 3D framework ().

elements.content: There are some main factors influencing the ionothermal synthesis, such as the dosage of ILs, the molar ratio of the reactants and ILs, the pH values of the reaction systems, reaction time and temperature, crystallization time, and so on. During the course of synthesizing compounds 1−4, we did many comparison experiments. First, we tried to synthesize the four compounds in aqueous solutions or common organic solvents, with the same molar ratio of reagents and pH values as that in ionothermal syntheses. However, only isolated Dawson anions could be obtained from aqueous solutions under synthetic conditions similar to those for 1. And under similar synthetic conditions as for 2−4, only inorganic−organic hybrid supermolecules composed of Dawson anions and organic ligands were obtained from aqueous solutions. Second, under ionothermal conditions, we changed the molar ratio and dosage of various reactants and the pH value of the reaction system to find the optimal synthetic conditions for the syntheses of compounds 2−4. We found (1) when the molar ratio of reagents [Bmim]Br: Na2WO4·2H2O is above 3:1 or below 2:1, the crystal quality of the obtained crystals was poor. When the amount of Na2WO4·2H2O or 85% H3PO4 was increased or decreased over 25%, no crystal was obtained, and when CuCl2·2H2O and the organic ligands were increased or decreased over 25%, the crystals were not very good. (2) When the pH value remained between 4 and 5, compounds 1−4 were successfully obtained. However, when the pH value was between 2 and 3.5, only organic−inorganic hybrid supermolecules based on Dawson anions were obtained, and when the pH value was between 5.5 and 7, only Cu-containing MOFs were obtained. The well-known pH dependence of POMs (α-P2W18) in aqueous solution is stable in the range of 2−4.5. In aqueous solutions from β to α isomerization occurs above pH 2, and the α-P2W18 aqueous solutions are stable below pH 4.5.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−4 were determined under the nitrogen atmosphere by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (see ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that the chemical decomposition starts at 200 °C and ends at 450 °C with a weight loss of 8.50%, equivalent to the loss of one Tea and three Bmim molecules (Calcd: 8.14%). The TGA curve of 2 indicates two weight loss processes. The one (7.03%) from 210 to 300 °C is attributed to the loss of two free Bbi organic ligand molecules (Calcd: 7.16%). The other weight loss (5.44%) from 300 to 400 °C corresponds to the removal of 1.5 coordinated Bbi ligands (Calcd: 5.27%). For 3, the first weight loss from 40 to 100 °C (2.02%) is equivalent to the loss of three water molecules (Calcd: 1.03%). The second weight loss (13.06%) from 250 to 350 °C corresponds to the loss of two Mimin and three Bbi ligands (Calcd: 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (3.73%) from 50 to 200 °C is attributed to the loss of free Bbi ligands (Calcd: 3.54%) and the other (8.04%) from 400 to 500 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated Btp and Bbtz ligands (Calcd: 7.58%).

Thermal Analysis

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-4 were determined under the nitrogen atmosphere by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (see ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that the chemical decomposition starts at 200 °C and ends at 450 °C with a weight loss of 8.50%, equivalent to the loss of one Tea and three Bmim molecules (Calcd: 8.14%). The TGA curve of 2 indicates two weight loss processes. The one (7.03%) from 210 to 300 °C is attributed to the loss of two free Bbi organic ligand molecules (Calcd: 7.16%). The other weight loss (5.44%) from 300 to 400 °C corresponds to the removal of 1.5 coordinated Bbi ligands (Calcd: 5.27%). For 3, the first weight loss from 40 to 100 °C (2.02%) is equivalent to the loss of three water molecules (Calcd: 1.03%). The second weight loss (13.06%) from 250 to 350 °C corresponds to the loss of two Mimin and three Bbi ligands (Calcd: 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (3.73%) from 50 to 200 °C is attributed to the loss of free Bbi ligands (Calcd: 3.54%) and the other (8.04%) from 400 to 500 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated Btp and Bbtz ligands (Calcd: 7.58%).

elements.content: In order to investigate the electrochemical behaviors of 2−4, the three compounds have been used as modifiers to fabricate chemically modified carbon paste electrodes (2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe) due to their high thermal stability and low solubility in water and common organic solvents. The cyclic voltammetric behavior for 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at different scan rates was recorded, exhibiting four pairs of redox peaks in the potential ranging from +600 to −600 mV (Figure a,c,e). The first three redox processes correspond to three consecutive two electron precesses of the W centers, which are similar to other tungsten-containing POMs. The oxidation wave IV at +0.2, +0.17, and +0.15 V and its reduction counterpart IV′ are attributed to the redox processes of the CuII centers. It is noteworthy that 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe possess high stabilities. When the potential range is maintained between +600 and −600 mV, the peak currents remain almost unchanged over 200 cycles at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. After 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe were stored at room temperature for one month, the peak current decreased only 5% for 2-cpe, 6% for 3-cpe and 7% for 4-cpe, and could be renewed by squeezing a little carbon paste out of the tube. The high stability of 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe could be ascribed to the coordination interaction of polyoxoanion with copper−organic fragments that stabilize the polyoxoanions in the compound. Furthermore, the three compounds are insoluble in the acidic aqueous medium of this experiment, avoiding the loss of the modifier during measurements. Thus, 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe could be ideal electrode materials to investigate electrocatalytic properties.

Electrochemistry Study

The first three redox processes correspond to three consecutive two electron precesses of the W centers, which are similar to other tungsten-containing POMs. The oxidation wave IV at +0.2, +0.17, and +0.15 V and its reduction counterpart IV' are attributed to the redox processes of the CuII centers. It is noteworthy that 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe possess high stabilities. When the potential range is maintained between +600 and -600 mV, the peak currents remain almost unchanged over 200 cycles at a scan rate of 50 mV s-1. After 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe were stored at room temperature for one month, the peak current decreased only 5% for 2-cpe, 6% for 3-cpe and 7% for 4-cpe, and could be renewed by squeezing a little carbon paste out of the tube. The high stability of 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe could be ascribed to the coordination interaction of polyoxoanion with copper-organic fragments that stabilize the polyoxoanions in the compound. Furthermore, the three compounds are insoluble in the acidic aqueous medium of this experiment, avoiding the loss of the modifier during measurements. Thus, 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe could be ideal electrode materials to investigate electrocatalytic properties.

elements.content: Actually, 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe display good electrocatalytic activity to reduce nitrite (Figure b,d,f). At the 2-cpe, 3-cpe, and 4-cpe, with the addition of nitrite, all reduction peak currents of WVI centers increased while the corresponding oxidation peak currents dramatically decreased, suggesting that nitrite was reduced by reduced polyoxoanion species. Furthermore, the catalytic activities were enhanced with the increased extent of the polyoxoanion reduction. In contrast, the reduction of nitrite at a bare electrode generally requires a large overpotential and no obvious response was observed at a bare cpe.

elements.content: In a typical process, compounds 2−4 (15 mg) were respectively added into the 100 mL aqueous solution of rhodamine B (RhB) (1.8 × 10−5 mol L−1), then the obtained suspensions were magnetically stirred in the dark for about 30 min to ensure the equilibrium of the working solution. The solution was then exposed to UV irradiation from a 125 W Hg lamp at a distance of 4−5 cm between the liquid surface and the lamp. The solution was stirred during irradiation. At given time intervals, 3 mL aliquots were sampled and centrifuged to remove the particles. The filtrates were analyzed by UV−visible spectroscopy (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalysis Experiments

In a typical process, compounds 2-4 (15 mg) were respectively added into the 100 mL aqueous solution of rhodamine B (RhB) (1.8 × 10-5 mol L-1), then the obtained suspensions were magnetically stirred in the dark for about 30 min to ensure the equilibrium of the working solution. The solution was then exposed to UV irradiation from a 125 W Hg lamp at a distance of 4-5 cm between the liquid surface and the lamp. The solution was stirred during irradiation. At given time intervals, 3 mL aliquots were sampled and centrifuged to remove the particles. The filtrates were analyzed by UV-visible spectroscopy (Figure ).

elements.content: In the presence of compound 2, the rhodamine B (RhB) degrades from 100% to 28.4% during 6 h. The degradation rate curve of 2 is nearly linear, and the degradation rate is about 12% per hour. For compound 3, RhB degrades to 37.8% during 6 h and the degradation rate is 10.4% per hour. For compound 4, RhB degrades to 13.8% during 4 h and degradation rate is 21.53% per hour. In order to compare with compounds 2−4, the RhB degradation in the presence of K6P2W18O62 was also analyzed as shown in . As a heterogeneous photocatalyst, the PMOFs have the dual features of simultaneous adsorption of both reactants (the organic substrates and dioxygen dissolved in the reaction slurry) on the catalyst surface and absorption of the suitable light energy. The photocatalytic reaction occurs in the adsorbed phase (on the surface of the catalyst), and the model of activation of the catalysts is photonic activation by exciting the POM with light energy higher than the band gap of POM, which leads to an intramolecular O(2p) → W(5d) charge transfer and the formation of the excited-state species (POM)*.

elements.content: In conclusion, three new PMOFs constructed by Dawson anions, Cu atoms, and organic ligands were successfully designed and synthesized under ionothermal conditions, which represent the first examples of PMOFs synthesized by the ionothermal method. This work suggests that ionothermal synthesis will be a promising synthetic technique for assembling new PMOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, three new PMOFs constructed by Dawson anions, Cu atoms, and organic ligands were successfully designed and synthesized under ionothermal conditions, which represent the first examples of PMOFs synthesized by the ionothermal method. This work suggests that ionothermal synthesis will be a promising synthetic technique for assembling new PMOFs.

A mixture of [Bmim]Br (2 g, 4.6 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.6 g, 1.8 mmol), 85% H3PO4 (0.1 mL), and Tea (0.15 mL) were stirred for about half an hour at room temperature. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and kept at 180 °C for five days. After the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, it stood for one day. Then the autoclave was opened, and the obtained black crystals were filtered off, washed with acetone, and dried in a desiccator (yield 72% based on W). The initial and final pH values of the solutions are 4.50 and 7.01, respectively. Elemental analysis for H3(Tea)(Bmim)3[P2W18O62]·3H2O (1) calcd: C, 5.98; H, 1.00; N, 2.03; P, 1.28; W, 68.68 (%); found: C, 4.01; H, 1.01; N, 1.37; P, 1.32; W, 69.07 (%).

cln_elements.content: The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−4 were determined under the nitrogen atmosphere by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (see ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that the chemical decomposition starts at 200 °C and ends at 450 °C with a weight loss of 8.50%, equivalent to the loss of one Tea and three Bmim molecules (Calcd: 8.14%). The TGA curve of 2 indicates two weight loss processes. The one (7.03%) from 210 to 300 °C is attributed to the loss of two free Bbi organic ligand molecules (Calcd: 7.16%). The other weight loss (5.44%) from 300 to 400 °C corresponds to the removal of 1.5 coordinated Bbi ligands (Calcd: 5.27%). For 3, the first weight loss from 40 to 100 °C (2.02%) is equivalent to the loss of three water molecules (Calcd: 1.03%). The second weight loss (13.06%) from 250 to 350 °C corresponds to the loss of two Mimin and three Bbi ligands (Calcd: 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (3.73%) from 50 to 200 °C is attributed to the loss of free Bbi ligands (Calcd: 3.54%) and the other (8.04%) from 400 to 500 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated Btp and Bbtz ligands (Calcd: 7.58%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-4 were determined under the nitrogen atmosphere by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (see ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that the chemical decomposition starts at 200 °C and ends at 450 °C with a weight loss of 8.50%, equivalent to the loss of one Tea and three Bmim molecules (Calcd: 8.14%). The TGA curve of 2 indicates two weight loss processes. The one (7.03%) from 210 to 300 °C is attributed to the loss of two free Bbi organic ligand molecules (Calcd: 7.16%). The other weight loss (5.44%) from 300 to 400 °C corresponds to the removal of 1.5 coordinated Bbi ligands (Calcd: 5.27%). For 3, the first weight loss from 40 to 100 °C (2.02%) is equivalent to the loss of three water molecules (Calcd: 1.03%). The second weight loss (13.06%) from 250 to 350 °C corresponds to the loss of two Mimin and three Bbi ligands (Calcd: 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (3.73%) from 50 to 200 °C is attributed to the loss of free Bbi ligands (Calcd: 3.54%) and the other (8.04%) from 400 to 500 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated Btp and Bbtz ligands (Calcd: 7.58%).
